CLAUDE.md

This file provides guidance to Claude Code (claude.ai/code) when working with code in this repository.

Project Summary

Single-Facility Disease Transmission Model - A Java-based agent-based model (ABM) built with Repast Simphony 2.11.0 for simulating disease transmission in healthcare facilities, focusing on Carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE).

The model simulates patient flow through a facility over ~15 years (10-year burn-in + 5-year measurement period), tracking disease importation, transmission, clinical detection, active surveillance testing, and decolonization.

Build and Run Commands

Development Setup (Eclipse with Repast Simphony)

# Import project into Eclipse
# File → Import → General → Existing Projects into Workspace

# Compile and run through Eclipse
# Right-click project → Run As → Java Application
# Select SingleFacilityBuilder as main class
# Use launcher: launchers/single-facility Model.launch

Command-Line Build

make validate          # Compile and validate
make help              # Show available targets
make debug-classpath   # Debug configuration
make run-batch         # Run batch simulation

Configuration

  • Parameter defaults: single-facility.rs/parameters.xml
  • Batch configuration: single-facility.rs/batch_params.xml
  • Launch configuration: launchers/single-facility Model.launch

Core Architecture

Main Classes

  1. SingleFacilityBuilder - Main context builder, controls simulation lifecycle and output
  2. Facility - Healthcare facility container managing patient populations
  3. Person - Patient agents with disease states
  4. Disease/FacilityOutbreak - Disease transmission logic using modified SIS model
  5. Admission - Continuous patient admission process with importation

Key Parameters (parameters.xml)

  • longTermAcuteCareBeta (0.0615) - Transmission rate coefficient
  • importationRate (0.206) - Probability new patient arrives colonized
  • avgDecolonizationTime (387 days) - Average infection clearance time
  • isolationEffectiveness (0.5) - Transmission reduction when isolated
  • daysBetweenTests (14 days) - Active surveillance interval
  • doActiveSurveillanceAfterBurnIn (true) - Enable surveillance post burn-in
  • isBatchRun (false) - Batch mode vs. individual outputs

Output Files

Individual run outputs (when isBatchRun=false): - simulation_results.txt - Summary statistics - daily_population_stats.txt - Time series data - admissions.txt, transmissions.txt, clinicalDetection.txt, decolonization.txt, surveillance.txt - Event logs

Analysis: Use R/Quarto scripts in new_analysis/ folder to analyze outputs.

Important: Time Representation

Time in this model is continuous floating-point in days: - 1.0 = Start of day 1 - 1.5 = Midday of day 1 - Default total: 5475 ticks (15 years)

Code Standards and Extensions

For detailed coding standards, analysis guidelines, and extension patterns, see: - Copilot Instructions: .github/copilot-instructions.md (primary reference) - Local Instructions: .copilot-instructions.md - Full Documentation: README.md, QUICK_START.md, TECHNICAL_DOCS.md

Extension Guidelines (Summary)

  • New disease types: Extend Disease class, update parameters.xml
  • Surveillance strategies: Extend FacilityOutbreak transmission logic
  • Multi-facility networks: Use Region class to coordinate Facility objects

Java Style

  • Follow Google Java Style Guide (referenced in copilot instructions)
  • Use Repast Simphony patterns: @ScheduledMethod, RunEnvironment.getInstance()
  • Output files use PrintWriter and FileWriter

Performance Notes

  • Typical run: 5-15 minutes on development machine
  • Batch runs: 2-5 minutes per run
  • Large populations (1000+): 30+ minutes
  • Memory: ~1-2 GB for typical parameters
  • Requires Java 11 (specified in Makefile)

Resources

  • Repast Documentation: https://repast.github.io/docs/
  • Repast User Guide: https://repast.github.io/docs/RepastReference/RepastReference.html
  • Google Java Style Guide: https://google.github.io/styleguide/javaguide.html
